newsitem.title: CHILE: United States denies protectionism in salmon spat.
newsitem.headline: United States denies protectionism in salmon spat.

text.p: U.S. ambassador Gabriel Guerra- Mondragon denied Friday protectionism by the U.S. government in a dispute over Chilean salmon imports, saying the claims of dumping were made by private American salmon producers.
"The North American government has absolutely no protectionist stance," Guerra-Mondragon told reporters at the U.S. embassy during Fourth of July celebrations.
"This was an action by private North American salmon producers who presented a complaint to the North American Commerce Department and the International Trade Commission."
U.S. salmon producers have accused their Chilean counterparts of dumping fresh Atlantic salmon in the American market and of receiving illegal state subsidies.
The Commerce Department began investigations into the claims Wednesday following a formal complaint in June from the American companies.
To prove dumping charges, the accuser must generally show the producer is selling below cost, or below the cost at which it sells its product in its home market.
Chile has said it will defend the salmon producers against the subsidy allegations, while the companies themselves are planning to spend millions of dollars on their legal defence.
Guerra-Mondragon dismissed comments from Chilean Foreign Minister Jose Miguel Insulza Thursday that U.S. anti-dumping laws could breach World Trade Organization rules.
"Our laws fall completely within the regulations agreed by the World Trade Organization," said Guerra-Mondragon.
U.S. supermarkets and restaurants account for 30 percent of Chile's total salmon exports, with shipments to the American market worth around $180 million.

In a separate trade dispute, Guerra-Mondragon said the U.S. government is studying an appeal against a San Francisco federal court ruling barring the agriculture department from issuing new import permits for logs and wood chips from several countries including Chile.
"The agriculture department is analyzing the decision of the judge and we are studying whether or not we appeal against the judge's decision," he said.
Chilean officials have said the ban on new permits could hit forestry exports worth around $100 million a year.
